content.description: A fun corner and good warm up for the area. Starts with a short scramble around a bush and into a few blue collar moves.
content.location: Right facing dihedral left of Rapture. One crack system right of huge tree right on the rim. Rap from a smaller tree right (if looking out into the canyon) to the bottom and scramble over someone's trash pile to the base.

content.description: Rap down the large tree 60ft to a ledge and build in the solid horizontal. The climb is 45ft to the climbers left of rapture. Climbing the flaring hands and OW crack or the fingers to thin hands crack with feet. Having a #4 is very nice.
content.location: Large golden corner system with broken crack on the right face. 45ft climbers left of rapture beneath large tree.

content.description: A less than typical Volunteer Route with broken features on reddish basalt. An easy start leads to ever steepening terrain, all the way to the top.
content.protection: Lots of small stuff, a couple hand sizes, nuts, and runners.
content.location: A lone line at the far left of the East End Wall, a couple hundred feet left of Golden Corner and Helix. Continue East along the South Side of the Rim to Volunteer Wash, separating the South Side from the North Side and the People's Court.... Walk along the rim back toward the East End Wall through a small group of Oak Trees to reach the top of the climb near a huge dead pine.

content.description: Climbs up behind the big pillar that golden corner goes up the right side of, then out the other side and up the offwidth. Start as for golden corner, up the first ten or so feet of offwidth then when possible climb in behind the pillar to the hand crack on the other side. It's probably best to hold off putting gear in until the hand crack to avoid rope drag. Climb the hand crack until the obvious exit from behind the pillar. If you keep going too high you'll get stuck, and you shouldn't have to take your helmet off for this bit. Once on the east side of the pillar grunt up the offwidth then follow the corner until possible to climb up right and scramble to the big tree at the top of Golden Corner. Avoid going up the gully with the barbed wire.
content.protection: I used a camalot #1, 2 #2s, and one #4, #5 and bumped a #6 with small cams for the belay. A very small wire placement is possible if you get your #6 stuck and want some protection while trying to get it out.

content.description:
The Ramshackle Wall extends from the falls to the East End Wall which it is separated from on the rim by a large gully. This section of the cliff is shattered and filled with abject hazards with regards to loose blocks. Seriously, be careful what you pull on. The few documented lines have seen quite a bit of traffic through the ages.

 There are pockets of good stone, and more routes could be done or rediscovered with some prudence and a solid work ethic.
